Μυρμιδόνων δ᾽ ἐπί τε κλισίας καὶ νῆας ἱκέσθην Hom. Il. 1. 328, … and came to the tents and the ships of the Myrmidons.

Under this category belongs the middle of collective motion. The Middle of collective motion is used for motions that are naturally and necessarily done by groups, such as gathering.[111]

οἳ μὲν ἐκήρυσσον, τοὶ δ᾽ ἠγείροντο μάλ᾽ ὦκα Hom. Il. 2.52 they made summons, and the men gathered full quickly.

Mid5. Mental Activity or Process[112] 

“The mental activity middle involves an animate subject that volitionally performs a mental activity, whereby the subject itself is mentally affected. In other words, the subject has two semantic roles: agent and experiencer.

There is no sharp boundary between the mental activity type and the mental process type. The crucial difference is that mental activities are volitional. There are, however, several verbs that can designate both mental processes and activities.”[113]

Middles of mental process represent the subject undergoing an emotional or cognitive mental affectedness, such as fearing, knowing, enjoying or remembering. The subject has the role of experiencer and the process could have an stimulus in an oblique case. [114]

ὅς κ᾽ εἴποι ὅ τι τόσσον ἐχώσατο Φοῖβος Ἀπόλλων Hom. Il. 1. 64 … who might say why Phoebus Apollo is so angry.

Under this category belongs the perception middle. Perception middle verbs represent the subject voluntarily perceiving an object through their sensory organs. Since the subject is mentally affected by perception, it has the role of experiencer. While the act of perceiving could be volitional or non-volitional, it seems that the perception middle verbs mainly express volitional perception.[115]

Mid6. Reciprocal Middle[116]

Reciprocal middle verbs involve events that naturally need more than one participant, acting toward each other in the same manner, meaning that the relation between each participant to the other one is the same.[117]

With a dual or plural subject the middle may indicate a reciprocal relation. So with verbs of contending, conversing (questioning, replying), greeting, embracing, etc. The reciprocal middle is often found with compounds of διά.

“οἱ ἀθληταὶ ἠγωνίζοντο” T. 1.6, the athletes contended

καταστάντες ἐμάχοντο 1. 49, when they had got into position they fought

ἀνὴρ ἀνδρὶ διελέγοντο 8. 93,  they conversed man with man

“ἐπιμείγνυσθαι ἀλλήλοις” X. C. 7.4.5,  to have friendly intercourse with one another

“ταῦτα διανεμοῦνται” L. 21.14, they will divide this up among themselves

So αἰτιᾶσθαι accuse, λυμαίνεσθαι maltreat, μέμφεσθαι blame, ἁμιλλᾶσθαι vie, παρακελεύεσθαι encourage one another.

Mid7. Spontaneous Process Middle

The subjects of spontaneous process middle verbs go through internal, physical changes of state without initiating it directly. The importance difference from passive is that in spontaneous process middles the agent is unknown or unidentifiable. Most middles of this type also have a causative active counterpart.[118] 

(...) πέλας τῶν κήπων (...), ἐν τοῖσι φύεται αὐτόματα ῥόδα, Hdt. 8.138.2 (...) near the gardens (...), where roses grow of themselves

αἰεὶ δὲ πυραὶ νεκύων καίοντο θαμειαί. Hom. Il. 1. 52 and constantly the pyres of the dead burned thick.

Passive Voice[119]

Pass1. Passive voice

The passive voice represents the subject as acted on:

ἐώθουν, ἐωθοῦντο, ἔπαιον, ἐπαίοντο X. C. 7.1.38, they pushed, were pushed, they struck, were struck

The direct object of an active verb becomes the subject of the passive:

 ἡ ἐπιστολὴ ὑπὸ τοῦ διδασκάλου γράφεται the letter is written by the teacher (active ὁ διδάσκαλος γράφει τὴν ἐπιστολήν).

The passive has been developed from the middle. With the exception of some futures and the aorist, the middle forms do duty as passives: αἱρεῖται takes for himself, i.e. chooses, and is chosen. (For this development of the passive, cp. the reflexive use in se trouver, sich finden.) So κέχυται has poured itself, has been poured. In Homer there are more perfect middles used passively than any other middle tenses. The agent of the passive is regularly expressed by ὑπό and the genitive; sometimes by ἀπό, διά, ἐκ, παρά, πρός with the genitive, or by ὑπό with the dative (in poetry).

“φθονηθεὶς ὑπὸ τοὖ Οδυσσέως” X. M. 4.2.33 envied by Odysseus

“οὐκ ἠξίουν οὗτοι ἡγεμονεύεσθαι ὑφ᾽ ἡμῶν” T. 3.61, they did not think it right to be governed by us

The passive may have the sense allow oneself to be, get oneself: 

“ἐξάγοντές τε καὶ ἐξαγόυενοι” P. Cr. 48d, carrying and allowing ourselves to be carried across the border

“ἀπεχθήσει Γοργίᾳ” P. Phil. 58c,  you will incur the hatred of Gorgias

 The dative, or a prepositional phrase, is regularly used with the passive to denote the instrument, means, or cause. The agent may be viewed as the instrument: in prose, when persons are regarded as instruments, the dative is usually that of military accompaniment

The instrument of an action, when regarded as the agent, is personified, and may be expressed by ὑπό with the genitive:

 ἁλίσκεται  ὑπὸ τριήρους D. 53.6, he is captured by a trireme

&&Indicative

Ind1. Assertion[120]

The indicative states particular or general suppositions, makes affirmative or negative assertions, which may or may not be absolutely true. Thus, in assumptions:

ἐξήμαρτέ τις ἄκων: συγγνώμη ἀντὶ τιμωρίας τούτῳ D. 18.274, suppose someone involuntarily committed an offence; for him there is pardon rather than punishment

and often after καὶ δή:

“καὶ δὴ τεθνᾶσι” E. Med. 386, and suppose they are dead

The indicative may be used to express a doubtful assertion about a present or past action (negative μή or μὴ οὐ):

ἀλλ᾽ ἄρα . . . μὴ ὁ Κτήσιππος ἦν ὁ ταῦτ᾽ εἰπών P. Eu. 290e, but I suspect (i.e. perhaps) after all it was Ctesippus who said this

“ἀλλὰ μὴ τοῦτο οὐ καλῶς ὡμολογήσαμεν” P. Men. 89c, but perhaps we did not do well in agreeing to this

 Such sentences are often regarded as questions with the effect of doubtful affirmation.

Ind2. Unfulfilled Obligation[121]

With the imperfect indicative of impersonal expressions denoting obligation, propriety, necessity, or possibility, the action of a dependent infinitive is usually not realized.  Such expressions are ἔδει, χρῆν (or ἐχρῆν), προσῆκε, καιρὸς ἦν, ἄξιον ἦν, εἰκὸς ἦν, δίκαιον ἦν, αἰσχρὸν ἦν, ἐξῆν, καλῶς εἶχεν, verbals in -τόν or -τέον with ἦν, etc.

In present tense:

“τούσδε μὴ ζῆν ἔδει” S. Ph. 418, these men ought not to be alive

“τί σιγᾷς; οὐκ ἐχρῆν σιγᾶν” E. Hipp. 297, why art thou silent? Thou shouldst not be silent

“εἰκὸς ἦν ὑμᾶς . . . μὴ μαλακῶς, ὥσπερ νῦν, ξυμμαχεῖν” T. 6.78, you should not be slack in your alliance, as you are at present

In past tense, ἔδει σε ταῦτα ποιῆσαι (or ποιεῖν) you ought to have done this (but did not do it), ἐξῆν σοι ἐλθεῖν you might have gone (but did not go), ἐνῆν αὐτῷ ταῦτα ποιῆσαι he could have done this (almost equivalent to the potential indicative ταῦτα ἐποίησεν ἄν)

“ἔδει τὰ ἐνέχυρα τότε λαβεῖν” X. A. 7.6.23, I ought to have taken the pledges then

“ἄξιον ἦν ἀκοῦσαι” P. Eu. 304d, it would have been worth hearing

“μένειν ἐξῆν” D. 3.17, he might have remained

Ind3. Unattainable Wish[122]

A wish, referring to the present or past, which cannot be realized, is expressed by a past tense of the indicative with εἴθε or with εἰ γάρ (negative μή). The imperfect refers to present time, the aorist to past time (cp. Smyth 2304, 2305).

εἴθ᾽ εἶχες βελτἱους φρένας E. El. 1061, would that thou hadst (now) a better heart

“εἴθε σοι τότε συνεγενόμην” X. M. 1.2.46,  would that I had then been with thee

An unattainable wish may also be expressed by ὤφελον (ought) with the present or aorist infinitive:

ὤφελε Κῦρος ζῆν X. A. 2.1.4 would that Cyrus were (now) alive (Cyrus ought to be alive)

The negative is μή:

“μήποτ᾽ ὤφελον λιπεῖν τὴν Σκῦρον” S. Ph. 969, would that I had never left Scyros

εἴθε or εἰ γάρ (poet. αἴθε, ὡς) may be used before ὤφελον:

εἰ γὰρ ὤφελον οἷοί τε εἶναι οἱ πολλοὶ κακὰ ἐργάζεσθαι Pl. Cr. 44 d, would that the multitude were able to do evil

ἐβουλόμην followed by an infinitive may express an unattainable wish:

ἐβουλόμην μὲν οὐκ ἐρίζειν ἐνθάδε Ar. Ran. 866, I would that I were not contending here (as I am)  (ἐβουλόμην ἄν vellem, See P5 .)

&&Ind4. Counterfactual Indicative[123]

The indicative of the historical tenses with ἄν (κέν) may denote unreality:

“τότε δ᾽ αὐτὸ τὸ πρᾶγμ᾽ ἂν ἐκρίνετο ἐφ᾽ αὑτοῦ” D. 18.224, but the case would then have been decided on its own merits

“καί κεν πολὺ κέρδιον ἦεν” Γ 41,  and in that case it were far better

The imperfect refers to the present or the past, the aorist to the past (rarely to the present), the pluperfect to the present (less commonly to the past).

ἐβουλόμην ἄν (vellem) I should like or should have liked may express an unattainable wish:

ἐβουλόμην ἂν Σίμωνα τὴν αὐτὴν γνώμην ἐμοὶ ἔχειν L. 3.21,  I should have liked Simon to be (or I wish Simon were) of the same mind as myself

This use of the indicative with ἄν to denote unreality is not inherent in the meaning of the past tenses of that mood, but has been developed from the past potential with which the unreal indicative is closely connected.

Past Potential with ἄν:

The past tenses (usually the aorist, less commonly the imperfect) of the indicative with ἄν (κέν) denote past potentiality, probability (cautious statement), or necessity:[124]

“ὃ οὐκ ἂν ᾤοντο” T. 7.55, which they could not have expected

τίς γὰρ ἂν ᾠήθη ταῦτα γενέσθαι; D. 9.68  for who would have expected these things to happen?

ἔγνω ἄν τις X. C. 7.1.38, one might (could, would) have known

“ὑπό κεν ταλασίφρονά περ δέος εἷλεν” Δ 421, fear might have seized even a man of stout heart

This is especially frequent with τὶς and with the ideal second person:

ἐπέγνως ἄν X. C. 8.1.33, you would (could, might) have observed

Ind5. Iterative Indicative[125]

The imperfect and aorist with ἄν are used to express repeated or customary past action (post-Homeric):

“διηρώτων ἄν”P. A. 22b,  I used to ask

“ἂν ἔλεξεν” X. C. 7.1.10, he was wont to say

This construction is connected with the past potential and denoted originally what could or would take place under certain past circumstances. Thus:

ἀναλαμβάνων οὖν αὐτῶν τὰ ποιήματα . . . διηρώτων ἂν αὐτοὺς τί λέγοιεν P. A. 22b,  accordingly, taking up their poems, I used to (would) ask them (as an opportunity presented itself) what they meant

In actual use, since the action of the verb did take place, this construction has become a statement of fact.

Homer and the early poets use ἄν (κέν) with the future indicative with a conditional or limiting force:

καί κέ τις ὧδ᾽ ἐρέει Δ 176, and in such a case someone will (may) say thus

This use is found also in conditional relative sentences (Smyth 2565 b). In Attic ἄν is found with the future in a few passages which are now generally emended. In P. A. 29c there is an anacoluthon.

&&Ind6. In Subordinate Clause

Subjunctive

Subj1. Hortatory Subjunctive[126]

The hortatory subjunctive (present or aorist) is used to express a request or a proposal (negative μή). The hortatory use of the subjunctive compensates for the absence of an imperative of the first person and is more common in the first person plural than first person singular.

νῦν ἴωμεν καὶ ἀκούσωμεν τοῦ ἀνδρός P. Prot. 314 b, let us go now and hear the man

μήπω ἐκεῖσε ἴωμεν P. Prot. 311 a, let's not go there yet  

ἄγε σκοπῶμενX. C. 5.5.15,  come, let us consider  

“φέρε δὴ περὶ τοῦ ψηφίσματος εἴπω” D. 19.234, let me now speak about the bill

Subj2. Prohibitive Subjunctive[127]

The subjunctive (in the second and third persons of the aorist) is often used to express prohibitions (negative μή).

“μηδὲν ἀθυμήσητε” X. A. 5.4.19, do not lose heart

For the aorist subjunctive the present imperative may be employed (Smyth 1840): μὴ ποιήσῃς (or μὴ ποίει) ταῦτα do not do this (not μὴ ποιῇς).

Less commonly in the third person, which usually represents the second:

“ὑπολάβῃ δὲ μηδείς” T. 6.84 and let no one suppose ( = μὴ ὑπολάβητε do not suppose).

The third person of the present subjunctive is rare:

μὴ τοίνυν τις οἴηται ( = μὴ οἰώμεθα) P. L. 861 E, let not any one think

οὐ μή with the subjunctive of the second person in the dramatic poets occasionally expresses a strong prohibition:

“οὐ μὴ ληρήσῃς” Ar. Nub. 367, don't talk nonsense

Subj3. Doubtful Assertion[128]

The present subjunctive with μή may express a doubtful assertion, with μὴ οὐ a doubtful negation. The idea of apprehension or anxiety (real or assumed) is due to the situation. A touch of irony often marks this use, which is chiefly Platonic. With μή (of what may be true):

μὴ ἀγροικότερον ᾖ τὸ ἀληθὲς εἰπεῖν P. G. 462e,  I suspect it's rather bad form (lit. too rude) to tell the truth

With μὴ οὐ (of what may not be true):

“ἀλλὰ μὴ οὐχ οὕτως ἔχῃ” P. Crat. 436b, but I rather think this may not be so

“μὴ οὐκ ᾖ διδακτὸν ἀρετή” P. Men. 94e, virtue is perhaps not a thing to be taught

In Homer μή with the independent subjunctive is used to indicate fear and warning, or to suggest danger:

μή τι χολωσάμενος ῥέξῃ κακὸν υἷας Ἀχαιῶν B 195, may he not (as I fear he may) in his anger do aught to injure the sons of the Achaeans

Subj4. Deliberative Subjunctive[129]

The deliberative subjunctive (present or aorist) is used in questions when the speaker asks what he is to do or say (negative μή). It is often used  in the first person.

εἴπωμεν ἢ σιγῶμεν; E. Ion 758,  shall we speak or keep silence?

τί δράσω; ποῖ φύγω; E. Med. 1271,  what am I to do? whither shall I fly?

μὴ φῶμεν; P. R. 554b, shall we not say?

τί τις εἶναι τοῦτο φῇ; ( = τί φῶμεν;) D. 19.88, how shall anyone say this is so? 

The subjunctive question does not refer to a future fact, but to what is, under the present circumstances, advantageous or proper to do or say. βούλει, βούλεσθε (poet. θέλεις, θέλετε) do you wish often precede the subjunctive:

βούλει σοι εἴπω; P. G. 521d, do you wish me to say to you?

Subj5. Anticipatory Subjunctive (Homeric Subjunctive)[130]

In Homer the subjunctive is often closely akin to the future indicative, and refers by anticipation to a future event (negative οὐ):

οὐ γάρ πω τοίους ἴδον ἀνέρας, οὐδὲ ἴδωμαι A 262, for never yet saw I such men, nor shall I see them

“καί νύ τις ὧδ᾽ εἴπῃσι” ξ 275, and one will say

ἄν (κέν) usually limits this subjunctive in Homer ( See Smyth 1813).

Subj6. Assimilation to the Subjunctive[131]

Conditional relative clauses and temporal clauses referring to future or general present time, if dependent on a subjunctive, take the subjunctive:

τῶν πραγμάτων τοὺς βουλευομένους (ἡγεῖσθαι δεῖ), ἵν᾽ ἃν ἐκείνοις δοκῇ, ταῦτα πράττηται D. 4.39, men of counsel must guide events in order that what they resolve shall be accomplished

“οὐδ᾽, ἐπειδὰν ὧν ἂν πρίηται κύριος γένηται, τῷ προδότῃ συμβούλῳ περὶ τῶν λοιπῶν ἔτι χρῆται” D. 18.47, nor when he has become master of what he purchases, does he any longer employ the traitor to advise him concerning his plans for the future

Subj7. In subordinate clause

Subjunctive is used in temporal, conditional and relative clauses with ἄν to represent actions that are occurring repeatedly or generically. This construction is expressed by iterative optative in historic sequence.[132]

ὃς ἂν δακρῦσαι μάλιστα τὴν θύσασαν παραχρῆμα ποιήσῃ πόλιν, οὗτος τὰ νικητήρια φέρει Plat. Laws 7.800d, and the man that succeeds at once in drawing most tears from the sacrificing city carries off the palm of victory.

Prospective subjunctive with ἄν indicates an action that is definitely or probably occurring in the future.

ὡς ἐγώ ὁπότερος ἂν σφῷν νῦν με μᾶλλον εὖ ποιῇ, τούτῳ παραδώσω τῆς πυκνὸς τὰς ἡνίας Aristoph. Kn. 1060; To whichever of you shall treat me best I hand over the reins of state.

Subjunctive dependent clauses, outside of the pure final sentence, regularly take “ἄν” except in the older language. The omission of “ἄν” is sometimes due to clerical error, sometimes perhaps to a sense of euphony, sometimes to a survival of the older construction.[133]

The present and aorist indicative and subjunctive (usually without ἄν) are regularly used in similes with ὡς, ὡς εἰ, ὡς εἴ τε as if, ὡς ὅτε, ὡς ὁπότε as when.  [134]

οἱ δ᾽, ὥς τ᾽ αἰγυπιοὶ . . . πέτρῃ ἐφ᾽ ὑψηλῇ μεγάλα κλάζοντε μάχωνται, ὣς οἱ κεκλήγοντες ἐπ᾽ ἀλλήλοισιν ὄρουσαν II 429, and they, like vultures who contend with loud screams on a lofty cliff, even so they rushed screaming against each other

Optative

Opt1. Optative of Wish[135]

In independent sentences the optative without ἄν is used to express a wish referring to the future (negative μή):

ὦ παῖ, γένοιο πατρὸς εὐτυχέστερος S. Aj. 550, ah, boy, mayest thou prove more fortunate than thy sire

From this use is derived the name of the mood (Lat. opto wish).

Under wishes are included execrations and protestations:

“ἐξολοίμην” Ar. Ach. 324, may I perish

“καί σ᾽ ἐπιδείξω, ἢ μὴ ζῴην, δωροδοκήσαντα” Ar. Eq. 833, and I will prove that you took bribes, or may I not live

The optative of wish is often introduced by εἰ γάρ, εἴθε (Hom. αι᾽ γάρ, αἴθε), or by εἰ, ὡς (both poetical):

“εἰ γὰρ γένοιτο” X. C. 6.1.38, would that it might happen

“ὡς ὄλοιτο” S. El. 126, may he perish (ὡς is properly an exclamation: how.)

The optative introduced by εἰ γάρ, etc. is sometimes explained as a protasis with the conclusion omitted:

εἴθε φίλος ἡμῖν γένοιο X. H. 4.1.38, oh, if you would become our friend

Wishes represented as hopeless are often  expressed in the postHomeric language by the past tenses of the indicative or by ὤφελον. An unattainable wish, referring to the present, may be expressed by the present optative in Homer:

εἴθ᾽ ἡβώοιμι H 157, would that I were young again

Opt2. Imperative Optative[136]

The optative may express a command or exhortation with a force nearly akin to the imperative:

“Χειρίσοφος ἡγοῖτο” X. A. 3.2.37, let Chirisophus lead

Opt3. Potential Optative[137]

The potential optative with ἄν states a future possibility, propriety, or likelihood, as an opinion of the speaker; and may be translated by may, might, can (especially with a negative), must, would, should (rarely will, shall). So in Latin velim, videas, cognoscas, credas.

“γνοίης δ᾽ ἂν ὅτι τοῦθ᾽ οὕτως ἔχει” X. C. 1.6.21, you may see that this is so

“ἅπαντες ἂν ὁμολογήσειαν” I. 11.5,  all would agree

ἡδέως ἂν ἐροίμην D. 18.64, I (would gladly ask) should like to ask

“οὐκ ἂν λάβοις” S. Ph. 103,  thou canst not take

“λέγοιμ᾽ ἂν τάδε” A. Supp. 928, I will tell this

The potential optative, which in Attic regularly takes ἄν , is occasionally found in Homer and later poetry in an earlier form, without that particle:

“ῥεῖα θεός γ᾽ ἐθέλων καὶ τηλόθεν ἄνδρα σαώσαι” γ 231, easily might a god, if he so willed, bring a man safe even from afar

“θᾶσσον ἢ λέγοι τις” E. Hipp. 1186, quicker than a man could speak

The potential optative with ἄν is used to soften the statement of an opinion or fact, or to express irony:

ἕτερόν τι τοῦτ᾽ ἂν εἴη D. 20.116, this is (would be) another matter

νοσοῖμ᾽ ἄν, εἰ νόσημα τοὺς ἐχθροὺς στυγεῖν A. Pr. 978,  I must be mad, if it is madness to hate one's foes

So often with ἴσως or τάχα perhaps.

The present and aorist are used of what will be, or what will prove to be, true (future realization of a present fact):

ἀρετὴ ἄρα, ὡς ἔοικεν, ὑγίειά τις ἂν εἴη P. R. 444d, virtue then, it seems, will (prove to) be a kind of health

 The perfect is used of what will prove to be the case as regards a completed action:

πῶς ἂν λελήθοι; X. S. 3. 6, how can it have escaped my knowledge?

Usually the perfect is here equivalent to the present.

Opt4. Assimilation[138]

When an optative of the principal clause refers to future time (potential optative and optative of wish), the subordinate clause takes the optative by assimilation in the following cases.

πῶς γὰρ ἄν (1832) τις, ἅ γε μὴ ἐπίσταιτο, ταῦτα σοφὸς εἴη; X. M. 4.6.7, for how could anyone be wise in that which he does not know?

τίς μισεῖν δύναιτ᾽ ἄν ὑφ᾽ οὗ εἰδείη καλός τε καὶ ἀγαθὸς νομιζόμενος; X. S. 8. 17, who could hate one by whom he knew that he was regarded as both beautiful and good?

“ἔρδοι τις ἣν ἕκαστος εἰδείη τέχνην” Ar. Vesp. 1431, would that every man would practise the craft that he understood

τίς ἂν . . . μόλοι (Smyth 1832), ὅστις διαγγείλειε τἀμ᾽ εἴσω κακά” E. Hel. 435, would that someone would come to report within my tale of woe

τεθναίην, ὅτε μοι μηκέτι ταῦτα μέλοι Mimnermus 1. 2, may I die when these things no longer delight me 

“ὁ μὲν ἑκὼν πεινῶν φάγοι ἂν ὁπότε βούλοιτο” X. M. 2.1.18, he who starves of his own free will can eat whenever he wishes

εἰ δὲ πάνυ σπουδάζοι φαγεῖν, εἴποιμ᾽ ἂν ὅτι παρὰ ταῖς γυναιξίν ἐστιν, ἕως παρατείναιμι τοῦτον κτλ. X. C. 1.3.11, but if he was very desirous of eating, I would tell him that “he was with the women” until I had tortured him, etc.

“ὄλοιο μήπω, πρὶν μάθοιμι” S. Ph. 961,  perish not yet . . . until I learn

πειρῴμην (ἂν) μὴ πρόσω ὑμῶν εἶναι, ἵνα, εἴ που καιρὸς εἴη, ἐπιφανείην X. C. 2.4.17, I will try to keep not far away from you, in order that, if there should be any occasion, I may show myself

&&Opt5. In subordinate clause

In subordinate clauses in the secondary or historic sequence, the optative may replace the original mood. This use of optative is limited to the subordinate clauses of the secondary sequence (imperfect, aorist, pluperfect) and does not appear in primary sequence (present, perfect, future).[139]

ὃ ... δέδοικ᾽ ἐγὼ μὴ πάθηθ᾽ ὑμεῖς, Dem. 9 65… what I certainly fear will be your experience

πολὺν μὲν φόβον ἡμῖν παρείχετε μή τι πάθητε Xen. Cyrop. 4.5.48; you filled us with apprehension lest something should happen to you

Optative without ἄν is used in indefinite subordinate clauses of the historic sequence.[140]

ὅκως γὰρ τειχήρεας ποιήσειε, τὸ ἐνθεῦτεν χώματα χῶν πρὸς τὰ τείχεα ἐπόρθεε Hdt. 1.162.2; he would drive the men within their walls and then build earthworks against the walls and so take the cities.

Past habitual conditionals have an iterative optative in protasis and an imperfect or pluperfect in apodosis:

εἴ πού τι ὁρῴη βρωτόν, διεδίδου X. A. 4.5.8 if ever he saw anything to eat anywhere, he always distributed it

“εἰ δέ τις καὶ ἀντείποι, εὐθὺς . . . ἐτεθνήκει” T. 8.66, but if any one even made an objection, he was promptly put to death

εἰ μὲν ἐπίοιεν οἱ Ἀθηναῖοι, ὑπεχώρουν, εἰ δ᾽ ἀναχωροῖεν, ἐπέκειντο T.7.79, if the Athenians advanced, they retreated; if they retired, they fell upon them

ἐτίμα δ᾽ εἴ τι καλὸν πράττοιεν, παρίστατο δ᾽ εἴ τις συμφορὰ συμβαίνοι X. Ag. 7.3,  he honoured them if ever they performed some noble action, and stood by them in times of misfortune (lit. if any misfortune befell)

The (potential) optative with ἄν is used in dependent sentences; in purpose clauses (2202 b), in object clauses after verbs of effort and verbs of fearing , in causal clauses, in result clauses, in the apodosis of conditional (see smyth 2356) and conditional relative sentences (see Smyth 2566).[141]

“ἐπεὶ διά γ᾽ ὑμᾶς αὐτοὺς πάλαι ἂν ἀπολώλειτε” D. 18.49 since you would long ago have perished had it depended on yourselves

δέομαι οὖν σου παραμεῖναι ἡμῖν: ὡς ἐγὼ οὐδ᾽ ἂν ἑνὸς ἥδιον ἀκούσαιμι ἢ σοῦ P. Pr. 335d accordingly I beg you to stay with us; because there is no one (in my opinion) to whom I should more gladly listen than to you.

“τοσούτου δεῖς ἐλέου τινὸς ἄξιος εἶναι ὥστε μισηθείης ἂν δικαιότατ᾽ ἀνθρώπων” D. 37.49 you are so far unworthy of compassion that you would be detested most justly of all men

 εἰ δέ τινες φοβοῦνται μὴ ματαία ἂν γένοιτο αὕτη ἡ κατασκευή, εἰ πόλεμος ἐγερθείη, ἐννοησάτω ὅτι κτλ. X. Vect. 4.41 if some are afraid that this condition of things may prove vain, if war should arise, let them (him) consider that, etc.

Subordinate clauses of indirect discourse retain the mode and tense of the direct form always after a primary tense, often after a historical tense. But after a historical tense they may change an indicative or subjunctive to an optative. [142]

Imperative[143]

Impr1. Command[144]

Under commands are included requests, entreaties, summons, prescriptions, exhortations, etc. . All imperative tenses refer to the future.

In exhortations ἄγε, φέρε, ἴθι (usually with δή, sometimes with νύν), often precede the imperative:

“ἄγε δὴ ἀκούσατε” X. Ap. 14, come listen

“ἄγετε δειπνήσατε” X. H. 5.1.18, go now, take your supper

“ἀλλ᾽ ἴθι εἰπέ” P. G. 489e, but come, say”

The imperative may be used in assumptions (hypothetical imperative), to make a concession, or to grant permission:

“ἐμοῦ γ᾽ ἕνεκ᾽ ἔστω” D. 20.14, let it be assumed as far as I am concerned

“οὕτως ἐχέτω ὡς σὺ λέγεις” P. S. 201c, assume it to be as you say

The third person may be used in questions:

οὐκοῦν κείσθω ταῦτα; P. L. 820e, shall these points be established?

Impr2. Prohibitions [145]

Prohibitions are expressed by μή with the present or aorist subjunctive in the first person plural; by μή with the present imperative or the aorist subjunctive in the second and third person singular or plural (cp. Smyth 1800). The aorist imperative is rare in prohibitions.

“μὴ θαύμαζε” P. G. 482a, don't be astonished

“μὴ θορυβεῖτε” P. A. 21a,  don't raise a disturbance

“τὰ μὲν ποίει, τὰ δὲ μὴ ποίει” P. Pr. 325d, do this and refrain from doing that

“μηδεὶς διδασκέτω” T. 1.86, let no one tell me

“μηδεὶς τοῦτ᾽ ἀγνοείτω” Aes. 3.6,  let no one be ignorant of this fact

“μηδεὶς νομισάτω” X. C. 7.5.73,  let no one think

“μήτ᾽ ἀπογνώτω μηδὲν μήτε καταγνώτω” Aes. 3.60;  let him neither acquit nor condemn in any way

Infinitive

-Inf1. As Subject or Predicate[146]

The infinitive may be used as subject, especially with quasi-impersonal verbs and expressions. Such quasi-impersonal verbs and expressions are δεῖ it is necessary, χρή (properly a substantive with ἐστί omitted) it is necessary, δοκεῖ it seems good, ἔστι it is possible, ἔξεστι it is in one's power, οἷόν τέ ἐστι it is possible, πρέπει and προσήκει it is fitting, συμβαίνει it happens; and many expressions formed by ἐστί and a predicate noun.

“γράμματα μαθεῖν δεῖ” Men. Sent. 96, to learn to read is necessary

τί χρὴ ποιεῖν; X. A. 2.1.16, what must be done?

κόσμος (ἐστὶ) καλῶς τοῦτο δρᾶν T. 1.5, to perform this well is a credit

πᾶσιν ἁδεῖν χαλεπόν (ἐστι) Solon 7, to please everybody is difficult 

“ἔδοξεν αὐτοῖς προϊέναι” X. A. 2.1.2,  it seemed best to them to proceed

“συμφέρει αὐτοῖς φίλους εἶναι” X. O. 11.23, it is for their interest to be friends

“ὥρα βουλεύεσθαι” P. Soph. 241b,  it is time for considering

“τὸ γὰρ γνῶναι ἐπιστήμην λαβεῖν ἐστιν” P. Th. 209e, for to learn is to get knowledge

-Inf2. As Object[147]

 The infinitive as object is used after almost any verb that requires another verb to complete its meaning. The tenses of this infinitive are timeless, and denote only the stage of action.

The infinitive may be the only expressed object, or it may be one of two expressed objects, of the leading verb.

The infinitive in indirect discourse is often used as the object of a verb.

“παίδευσις καλὴ διδάσκει χρῆσθαι νόμοις” X. Ven. 12.14, a good education teaches obedience to the laws

“διαγιγνώσκειν σε τοὺς ἀγαθοὺς καὶ τοὺς κακοὺς ἐδίδαξεν” X. M. 3.1.9,  he taught you to distinguish the good and the bad

“ἐβουλεύοντο ἐκλιπεῖν τὴν πόλιν” Hdt. 6.100, they planned to leave the city

“βασιλεὺς ἀξιοῖ σὲ ἀποπλεῖν” X. H. 3.4.25, the king asks that you sail away

πέμπουσιν . . . στρατεύεσθαι ἐπὶ Καρίαν X. H. 3.1.7, they send orders that he shall march upon Caria

“ἔδοξε πλεῖν τὸν Ἀλκιβιάδην” T. 6.29, it was decided that Alcibiades should sail

“φοβοῦμαι διελέγχειν σε” P. G. 457e,  I fear to refute you

“αἰσχύνομαι ὑμῖν εἰπεῖν τἀληθῆ” P. A. 22b, I am ashamed to tell you the truth

 “χαλᾶν λέγω σοι” S. O. C. 840,  I bid thee let go

-Inf3. Complementary Infinitives[148]

The infinitive serves to define the meaning of adjectives, adverbs, and substantives, especially those denoting ability, fitness, capacity, etc. (and their opposites), and generally those analogous in meaning to verbs which take the infinitive.

“ἱκανοὶ ἡμᾶς ὠφελεῖν” X. A. 3.3.18, able to assist us

“δεινὸς λέγειν, κακὸς βιῶναι” Aes. 3.174, skilled in speaking, evil in life

“οἷοι φιλεῖν” D. 25.2,  able to love

“ἕτοιμοί εἰσι μάχεσθαι” X. C. 4.1.1, they are ready to fight

“ἄρχειν ἀξιώτατος” X. A. 1.9.1, most worthy to govern

ὁδὸς . . . ἀμήχανος εἰσελθεῖν στρατεύματι X. A. 1. 2. 21, a road impracticable for an army to enter

χαλεπὸν διαβαίνειν X. A. 5. 6. 9,  hard to cross

“ἐπινοῆσαι ὀξεῖς” T. 1.70, quick to conceive

“κάλλιστα ἰδεῖν” X. C. 8.3.5, most splendid to behold

“οἱ παῖδες ὑμῖν ὀλίγου ἡλικίαν ἔχουσι παιδεύεσθαι” P. Lach. 187c, your children are almost of an age to be educated

“σχολή γε ἡμῖν μανθάνειν” X. C. 4.3.12,  we have leisure to learn

“ἀνάγκη πείθεσθαι” X. H. 1.6.8, there is need to obey

“περαίνειν ἤδη ὥρα” X. A. 3.2.32. it is high time to finish (see T1.1.)

“λόγος δυνατὸς κατανοῆσαι” P. Ph. 90c, a speech capable of being understood

The infinitive, with or without ὥστε or ὡς, may be used with ἤ than after comparatives, depending on an (implied) idea of ability or inability. ἢ ὥστε is more common than ἤ or ἢ ὡς.

“τὸ γὰρ νόσημα μεῖζον ἢ φέρειν” S. O. T. 1293,  for the disease is too great to be borne

“φοβοῦμαι μή τι μεῖζον ἢ ὥστε φέρειν δύνασθαι κακὸν τῇ πόλει συμβῇ” X. M. 3.5.17,  I fear lest some calamity befall the State greater than it can bear

“βραχύτερα ἢ ὡς ἐξικνεῖσθαι” X. A. 3.3.7,  too short to reach

-Inf4. Purpose, Result or Temporal Infinitive[149]

The infinitive may express purpose.

“ταύτην τὴν χώραν ἐπέτρεψε διαρπάσαι τοῖς Ἕλλησιν” X. A. 1.2.19, he gave this land over to the Greeks to plunder

τὸ ἥμισυ (τοῦ στρατεύματος) κατέλιπε φυλάττειν τὸ στρατόπεδον X. A. 5. 2. 1,  he left half (of the army) behind to guard the camp

ἰέναι ἐπὶ βασιλέα οὐκ ἐγίγνετο τὰ ἱερά X. A. 2. 2. 3, the sacrifices did not turn out (favourable) for going against the king

“Ἀριστάρχῳ . . . ἔδοτε ἡμέραν ἀπολογήσασθαι” X. H. 1.7.28,  you granted a day to Aristarchus to make his defence

ἡ θύρα ἡ ἐμὴ ἀνέῳκτο . . . εἰσιέναι τῷ δεομένῳ τι ἐμοῦ X. H. 5. 1. 14, my door stood open for any petitioner of mine to enter

“παρέχω ἐμαυτὸν ἐρωτᾶν” P. A. 33b, I offer myself to be questioned

τὰς γυναῖκας πιεῖν φερούσας X. H. 7.2.9, the women bringing (something) to drink

Infinitive of Result: The infinitive may be used with ὥστε (sometimes with ὡς) to denote a result, often an intended result. Several verbs, substantives, and adjectives usually taking the infinitive also admit ὥστε with the infinitive (Smyth 2271); and the infinitive is found where ὥστε with the infinitive might be expected:

μνημονεύουσιν ἀφεθέντα τοῦτον ἐλεύθερον εἶναι D. 29.25, they recall that he was emancipated (lit. released so as to be free)

Here the redundant infinitive expresses an intended result. This redundant use of εἶναι is common in Homer and Herodotus.

πρίν takes the infinitive in Attic especially when the principal clause is affirmative. The infinitive must be used, even with negative clauses, when πρίν must mean only before (and not until).

“οἱ καὶ πρὶν ἐμὲ εἰπεῖν ὁτιοῦν εἰδότες” D. 18.50, who know even before I say anything at all

“σύνιστε μὲν καὶ πρὶν ἐμὲ λέγειν” Aes. 1.116, you know as well as I do even before I proceed to set forth in detail the matter of my speech

ἀπετράποντο ἐς τὴν πόλιν πρὶν ὑπερβαίνειν T. 3.24, they turned back to the city before they attempted to scale the wall

Inf5. Absolute Infinitive[150]

Certain idiomatic infinitives are used absolutely in parenthetical phrases to limit the application of a single expression or of the entire sentence. This is common with verbs of saying:

ἀληθές γε ὡς ἔπος εἰπεῖν οὐδὲν εἰρήκασιν P. A. 17a, not one word of truth, I may say, did they utter

ἀγαθὸν μὲν ἁπλῶς εἰπεῖν οὐδὲν γέγονε τῇ πόλει P. A. 1.33, in a word the State gained no advantage Dinarchus

Especially common is the absolute εἶναι in ἑκὼν willingly, intentionally, if you can help it, usually in negative or quasi-negative statements (ἑκών may be inflected). Also in τὸ κατὰ τοῦτον (ἐπὶ τούτῳ) εἶναι as far as he is concerned, ὡς . . . εἶναι as far as . . . is concerned, τὸ νῦν εἶναι at present. Examples:

“οὐδὲ ξένοις ἑκὼν εἶναι γέλωτα παρέχεις” X. C. 2.2.15, nor do you intentionally cause strangers to laugh

“ἑκοῦσα εἶναι οὐκ ἀπολείπεται” P. Phae. 252a,  it is not willingly separated

τό γε ἐπ᾽ ἐκεῖνον εἶναι ἐσώθης (ἄν) L. 13.58,  so far, at least, as it depended on him you would have been saved

Some other expressions: ἐμοὶ δοκεῖν, ὡς ἐμοὶ δοκεῖν, ὡς ἐμοὶ κρῖναι as it seems to me, in my opinion, (ὡς) εἰκάσαι to make a guess, (ὡς) συμβάλλειν to compare, (ὡς) ἀκοῦσαι to the ear, ὡς ὑμομνῆσαι to recall the matter, ὅσον γέ μ᾽ εἰδέναι as far as I know, etc.; ὀλίγου δεῖν, μικροῦ δεῖν almost, all but. Examples:

ὁ γὰρ Κτήσιππος ἔτυχε πόρρω καθεζόμενος τοῦ Κλεινίου, ἐμοὶ δοκεῖν P. Eu. 274b, for Ctesippus, it seems to me, happened to be sitting at a distance from Clinias

“μικροῦ δεῖν τρία τάλαντα” D. 27.29, almost three talents

Inf6. Infinitive of Commands, Wishes, and Exclamations[151]

The infinitive may be used for the second person of the imperative. The person addressed is regarded as the subject. This infinitive is more common in poetry than in prose (where it has a solemn or formal force).

θαρσῶν νῦν, Διόμηδες, ἐπὶ Τρώεσσι μάχεσθαι E 124, with good courage now, Diomed, fight against the Trojans

σὺ δέ, Κλεαρίδα . . . τὰς πύλας ἀνοίξας ἐπεκθεῖν T. 5.9., but do you, Clearidas, open the gates and sally forth

The infinitive with a subject accusative may be used in the sense of the optative of wish.

“θεοὶ πολῖται, μή με δουλείας τυχεῖν” A. Sept. 253,  ye gods of my country, may bondage not be my lot!

ὦ Ζεῦ, ἐκγενέσθαι μοι Ἀθηναίους τείσασθαι  Hdt. 5.105, oh Zeus, that it be granted to me to punish the Athenians!

The infinitive is often used in exclamations of surprise or indignation. The subject stands in the accusative.

“ἐμὲ παθεῖν τάδε” A. Eum. 837,  that I should suffer this!

“τοιουτονὶ τρέφειν κύνα” Ar. Vesp. 835,  to keep a dog like that!

Inf7. Articular Infinitive[152]

The articular infinitive, while having the character of a substantive, retains the functions of a verb. The negative of the articular infinitive is μή. The articular infinitive is treated as subject, predicate noun, and object like the simple infinitive. It may indicate time (after verbs of saying or thinking), or may be timeless. It admits the constructions of an ordinary substantive:

Nom. τὸ ποιεῖν making or to make, τὸ ποιήσειν, τὸ ποιῆσαι, τὸ πεποιηκέναι

Gen. τοῦ ποιεῖν of making, τοῦ ποιήσειν, τοῦ ποιῆσαι, etc.

Dat. τῷ ποιεῖν for making, by making, τῷ ποιήσειν, τῷ ποιῆσαι, etc.

Acc. τὸ ποιεῖν, τὸ ποιήσειν, τὸ ποιῆσαι, etc.

“νέοις τὸ σιγᾶν κρεῖττόν ἐστι τοῦ λαλεῖν”Men. Sent. 387,  in the young silence is better than speech

“τὸ Πελοποννησίους αὐτοῖς μὴ βοηθῆσαι παρέσχεν ὑμῖν . . . Σαμίων κόλασιν” T. 1.41, the fact that the Peloponnesians did not come to their assistance enabled you to punish the Samians

“τοῦ πιεῖν ἐπιθυμίᾳ” T. 7.84,  from desire to drink

πρὸς τὴν πόλιν προσβαλόντες ἐς ἐλπίδα ἦλθον τοῦ ἑλεῖν T. 2.56,  they attacked the city and entertained hopes of taking it

“τοῦ θαρσεῖν τὸ πλεῖστον εἰληφότες” T. 4.34. having gained the greatest amount of courage

τί οὖν ἐστιν . . . τοῦ τοῖς φίλοις ἀρήγειν κάλλιον; X. C. 1.5.13, what then is nobler than to help one's friends?

“ἐπέσχομεν τοῦ δακρύειν” P. Ph. 117e, we desisted from weeping

ἀντὶ τοῦ ἐπὶ Καρίαν ἰέναι . . . ἐπὶ Φρυγίας ἐπορεύετο X. H. 3.4.12,  instead of going against Caria, he marched toward Phrygia

“ἄνευ τοῦ σωφρονεῖν” X. M. 4.3.1, without exercising self-control

“ἵνα . . . ἀπιστῶσι τῷ ἐμὲ τετιμῆσθαι ὑπὸ δαιμόνων” X. Ap. 14,  that they may distrust my having been honoured by divine powers

τῷ ζῆν ἐστί τι ἐναντίον, ὥσπερ τῷ ἐγρηγορέναι τὸ καθεύδειν; P. Ph. 71c,  is it something opposed to living, as sleeping to waking?

πῶς ἔχεις πρὸς τὸ ἐθέλειν ἂν ἰέναι ἄκλητος ἐπὶ δεῖπνον; P. S. 174a, how do you feel about being willing to go uninvited to supper?

“τὸ σπεύδειν δέ σοι παραινῶ” S. Ph. 620,I commend speed to thee

 καρδίας δ᾽ ἐξίσταμαι τὸ δρᾶν S. Ant. 1105, I withdraw from my resolution so as to ( = and) do this thing

μαθὼν γὰρ οὐκ ἂν ἀρνοίμην τὸ δρᾶν S. Ph. 118, when I am informed, I will not refuse the deed

“τὸ προθυμεῖσθαι δὲ συναύξειν τὸν οἶκον ἐπαιδεύομεν αὐτήν” X. O. 9.12, we trained her to show zeal in assisting to increase our estate

“τὸ ἐρᾶν ἔξαρνος εἶ” P. Lys. 205a,  you refuse to love

Participle

Partic1. Attributive and substantival Participle[153]

The attributive participle (with any modifier), with or without the article, modifies a substantive like any other adjective.

“ὁ ἐφεστηκὼς κίνδυνος τῇ πόλει” D. 18.176, the danger impending over the State

οἱ ὄντες ἐχθροί D. 6. 15,  the existing enemies

ὁ παρὼν καιρός D. 3. 3,  the present crisis

“τὸ Κοτύλαιον ὀνομαζόμενον ὄρος” Aes. 3.86, the mountain called Cotylaeum

“ὁ μὴ γαμῶν ἄνθρωπος οὐκ ἔχει κακά” Men. Sent. 437, the unmarried man has no troubles

The substantive with which the attributive participle (with the article) agrees directly, may be omitted, the participle thus becoming a substantive (Smyth 1153 b, and N. 1).

“ὁ οἴκαδε βουλόμενος ἀπιέναι” X. A. 1.7.4, whoever wants to go home

Neuter participles are often substantival, as τὰ δέοντα duties.

“ὁ τὴν γνώμην ταύτην εἰπών”T. 8.68,  the one who gave this opinion

“ὁ ἐνταῦθ᾽ ἑαυτὸν τάξας τῆς πολιτείας εἴμ᾽ ἐγώ” D. 18.62, the man who took this position in the State was I

A participle may be modified by adjectives or take a genitive, when its verbal nature has ceased to be felt:

“τὰ μικρὰ συμφέροντα τῆς πόλεως” D. 18.28, the petty interests of the State

Partic2. Circumstantial Participle[154]

The circumstantial participle is added, without the article, to a noun or pronoun to set forth some circumstance under which an action, generally the main action, takes place. The circumstantial participle thus qualifies the principal verb of the sentence like an adverbial clause or supplementary predicate. The circumstantial participle expresses simply circumstance or manner in general. It may imply various other relations, such as time, manner, means, cause, purpose, concession, condition, etc. But it is often impossible to assign a participle exclusively to any one of these relations (which are purely logical), nor can all the delicate relations of the participle be set forth in systematic form.

If the subject of the participle is not identical with the noun or pronoun subject or object of the leading verb, it forms an absolute participle clause of either genitive or accusative absolute (Explained under Partic3. and Partic4.)

(οἱ ἄνθρωποι) λιπόντες τὴν ὁδὸν φεύγοντες ὀλίγοι ἀπέθνῃσκον X. A. 4.2.7, by leaving the road and making off only a few were killed

“προπέμψαντες κήρυκα πόλεμον προεροῦντα” T. 1.29, having sent a herald in advance to proclaim war

“ἅπερ καὶ ἀρχόμενος εἶπον” T. 4.64, as I said at the outset

“τελευτῶν ἐχαλέπαινεν” X. A. 4.5.16, at last he became angry

Expressing Manner:

“παρήλαυνον τεταγμένοι” X. A. 1.2.16, they marched past in order

 κραυγὴν πολλὴν ἐποίουν καλοῦντες ἀλλήλους X.A. 2. 2. 17,  they made a loud noise by calling to each other

“προείλετο μᾶλλον τοῖς νόμοις ἐμμένων ἀποθανεῖν ἢ παρανομῶν ζῆν” X. M. 4.4.4, he preferred rather to abide by the laws and die than to disobey them and live

“ἄνοιγ᾽ ἀνύσας” Ar. Nub. 181, hurry up and open

“ἔκπλουν ποιεῖται λαθὼν τὴν φυλακήν” T. 1.65 he sailed out unobserved by the guard (cp. Smyth 2096 f)

“φλυαρεῖς ἔχων” P. G. 490e,  you keep trifling

τοῦτον οὐδεὶς χαίρων ἀδικήσει P. G. 510 d, no one will wrong him with impunity

Expressing Means (often the present participle):

“λῃζόμενοι ξῶσι” X. C. 3.2.25, they live by pillaging

Expressing Cause:

“Παρύσατις . . . ὑπῆρχε τῷ Κύρῳ, φιλοῦσα αὐτὸν μᾶλλον ἢ τὸν βασιλεύοντα Ἀρταξέρξην” X. A. 1.1.4, Parysatis favoured Cyrus because she loved him more than she did Artaxerxes the king

“ἀπείχοντο κερδῶν αἰσχρὰ νομίζοντες εἶναι” X. M. 1.2.22, they held aloof from gains because they thought them disgraceful

τί γὰρ δεδιότες σφόδρα οὕτως ἐπείγεσθε; X. H. 1.7.26, for what are you afraid of, that you are so desperately in haste?

Expressing Purpose or Object: The future (sometimes the present) participle is used to denote purpose, especially after verbs denoting to come, go, send, summon, etc. Thus:

“προπέμψαντες κήρυκα πόλεμον προεροῦντα” T. 1.29, having sent a herald in advance to proclaim war

ὁ βάρβαρος ἐπὶ τὴν Ἑλλάδα δουλωσόμενος ἦλθεν T. 1. 18, the barbarians proceeded against Greece with the purpose of enslaving it

συνεκάλεσαν ἀπὸ τῶν πόλεων ἁπασῶν ἀκουσομένους (Smyth 2052 a) τῆς παρὰ βασιλέως ἐπιστολῆς X. H. 7.1.39,  they summoned from all the cities men to listen to the letter from the king

Expressing Any Attendant Circumstance:

“συλλέξας στράτευμα ἐπολιόρκει Μίλητον” X. A. 1.1.7, having collected an army he laid siege to Miletus

παραγγέλλει τῷ Κλεάρχῳ λαβόντι ἥκειν ὅσον ἦν αὐτῷ στράτευμα X. A. 1. 2. 1,  he gave orders to Clearchus to come with all the force he had

“ἔχων στρατιὰν ἀφικνεῖται” T. 4.30, he arrives with an army

Partic3. Circumstantial Participle - Genitive Absolute[155]

A circumstantial participle agreeing with a genitive noun or pronoun which is not in the main construction of the sentence, stands in the genitive absolute. Like other circumstantial participles, the genitive absolute expresses time, cause, condition, concession, or simply any attendant circumstance.

Time:

“ταῦτ᾽ ἐπράχθη Κόνωνος στρατηγοῦντος” I. 9.56, these things were effected while Conon was in command

“τούτων λεχθέντων ἀνέστησαν” X. A. 3.3.1, this said, they rose

“Ἠϊόνα . . . Μήδων ἐχόντων πολιορκίᾳ εἷλον” T. 1.98,  they blockaded and captured Eïon which was held by the Medes

Cause:

“τῶν σωμάτων θηλυνομένων καὶ αἱ ψυχαὶ ἀρρωστότεραι γίγνονται” X. O. 4.2,  by the enfeebling of the body, the spirit too is made weaker

Opposition or Concession:

καὶ μεταπεμπομένου αὐτοῦ οὐκ ἐθέλω ἐλθεῖν X. A. 1.3.10,  even though he is sending for me, I am unwilling to go

Condition:

οἴομαι καὶ νῦν ἔτι ἐπανορθωθῆναι ἂν τὰ πράγματα τούτων γιγνομένων D. 9.76,  if these measures should be taken, I am of the opinion that even now our situation might be rectified

Attendant Circumstance:

Κῦρος ἀνέβη ἐπὶ τὰ ὄρη οὐδενὸς κωλύοντος X. A. 1.2.22, Cyrus ascended the mountains without opposition (lit. no one hindering) (or since no one opposed him).

Partic4. Circumstantial Participle - Accusative Absolute[156]

A participle stands in the accusative absolute, instead of the genitive, when it is impersonal, or has an infinitive as its subject (as under C).

When impersonal, such participles have no apparent grammatical connection with the rest of the sentence.

οὐδεὶς τὸ μεῖζον κακὸν αἱρήσεται ἐξὸν τὸ ἔλαττον (αἱρεῖσθαι) P. Pr. 358d, no one will choose the greater evil when it is possible to choose the less

ἧς (βουλῆς) νῦν ἀξιοῖ τυχεῖν οὐ μετὸν αὐτῷ L. 31.32, to which he now claims admission though he has no right

“δῆλον γὰρ ὅτι οἶσθα μέλον γέ σοι” P. A. 24d, for of course you know because it concerns you

μετεμέλοντο ὅτι μετὰ τὰ ἐν Πύλῳ, καλῶς παρασχόν, οὐ ξυνέβησαν T. 5.14,  they repented that after what had occurred at Pylos, although a favourable occasion had presented itself, they had not come to terms

“εἰρημένον δ᾽ αὐταῖς ἀπαντᾶν ἐνθάδε . . . εὕδουσι κοὐχ ἥκουσιν” Ar. Lys. 13, though it was told them to meet here, they sleep and have not come

προσταχθέν μοι ὑπὸ τοῦ δήμου Μένωνα ἄγειν εἰς Ἑλλήσποντον D. 50.12, a command having been given (it having been commanded) me by the people to convey Menon to the Hellespont

Adjectives with ὄν: ἄδηλον ὄν, δυνατὸν ὄν, ἀδύνατον ὄν, αἰσχρὸν ὄν, καλὸν ὄν, χρεών (χρεώ ¨ ὄν), etc.

“σὲ οὐχὶ ἐσώσαμεν . . . οἷόν τε ὂν καὶ δυνατόν” P. Cr. 46a, we did not rescue you although it was both feasible and possible

”ὡς οὐκ ἀναγκαῖον (ὄν) ““τὸ κλέπτειν, αἰτιᾷ τὸν κλεπτοντα” X. C. 5.1.13, on the ground that stealing is not necessary you accuse the thief

The participle of a personal verb may be used absolutely if it is preceded by ὡς or ὥσπερ. Thus:

ηὔχετο πρὸς τοὺς θεοὺς τἀγαθὰ διδόναι, ὡς τοὺς θεοὺς κάλλιστα εἰδότας ὁποῖα ἀγαθά ἐστ X. M. 1.3.2, ι (Socrates) prayed to the gods that they would give him good things, in the belief that the gods know best what sort of things are good

“σιωπῇ ἐδείπνουν, ὤσπερ τοῦτο προστεταγμένον αὐτοῖς” X. S. 1. 11,  they were supping in silence just as if this had been enjoined upon them

Partic5. Supplementary Participle[157]

The supplementary participle completes the idea of the verb by showing that to which its action relates. The supplementary participle agrees either with the subject or with the object of the main verb; with the subject when the verb is intransitive or passive, with the object when the verb is transitive.

“οὔποτ᾽ ἐπαυόμην ἡμᾶς οἰκτίρων”X. A. 3.1.19,  I never ceased pitying ourselves

“τοὺς πένητας ἔπαυσ᾽ ἀδικουμένους” D. 18.102, I put a stop to the poor being wronged

ἑώρων οὐ κατορθοῦντες καὶ τοὺς στρατιώτας ἀχθομένους T. 7.47, they saw that they (themselves) were not succeeding and that the soldiers were indignant

“ἀδικοῦντα φίλιππον ἐξήλεγξα” D. 18.136, I proved that Philip was acting unjustly

“εὐθὺς ἐλεγχθήσεται γελοῖος ὤν” X. M. 1.7.2, he will straightway be proved to be ridiculous

With verbs of emotion (rejoicing and grieving) the participle often denotes cause.

“χαίρω διαλεγόμενος τοῖς σφόδρα πρεσβύταις” P. R. 328d, I like to converse with very old men

“οὐκ ἀγαπῶ ζῶν ἐπὶ τούτοις” I. 12.8, I am not content to live on these conditions

“οὐκ ἂν ἀχθοίμην μανθάνων” P. Lach. 189a,  I should not be annoyed at learning

“χαλεπῶς ἔφερον οἰκίας κατελείποντες” T. 2.16, they took it hard at abandoning their homes

“μετεμέλοντο τὰς σπονδὰς οὐ δεξάμενοι” T. 4.27,  they repented not having accepted the truce

“οὔ μοι μεταμέλει οὕτως ἀπολογησαμένῳ” P. A. 38e, I do not repent having made such a defence

Article

Art1. Particular article[158]

The article ὁ, ἣ, τό marks objects as definite and known. The particular article denotes individual persons or things as distinguished from others of the same kind. The particular article defines objects that are well known, are already mentioned or in the mind of the speaker or writer, are particularized by an attributive or by a following description, or marked as usual or proper under the circumstances. Thus:

 μαίνεται ἅνθρωπος P. Phae. 268c, the man is mad (a definite person, distinguished from other men)

ὁ τῶν ἑπτὰ σοφώτατος Σόλων P. Tim. 20d, Solon the wisest of the Seven (Sages)

εἶπον ὅτι τάλαντον ἀργυρίου ἕτοιμος εἴην δοῦναι . . . ὁ δὲ λαβὼν τὸ τάλαντον κ.τ.λ. L. 12.9-10, I said that I was ready to give him a talent of silver . . . and he taking the talent, etc.

“λαβε τὸ βιβλίον” P. Th. 143c, take the book

“βουλόμενος τὴν μάχην ποιῆσαι” T. 4.91, wishing to fight the battle

“ὁ δῆμος ὁ Ἀθηναίων” Aes. 3.116, the people of the Athenians

“λέγε τὴν ἐπιστολήν, ἣν ἔπεμψεν” D. 18.39, read the letter that he sent

τὸ μέρος τῶν ψήφων ὁ διώκων οὐκ ἔλαβεν D. 18.103,  the prosecutor did not get the (requisite) part of the votes

Art2. as Substantivizer[159]

The article has the power to make a substantive of any word or words to which it is prefixed. It can be used with adjectives, participles, prepositional phrases, adverbs, attributive genitives, and whole word groups, sentences and clauses:

ἐπεὶ δ᾽ οἱ σὺν ταῖς γυναιξὶ προϊόντες ἐνέπεσον εἰς τοὺς ἐν τῷ ὄρει, κραυγήν τε εὐθὺς ἐποίουν καὶ φεύγοντες ἡλίσκοντο πολλοὶ γε αὐτῶν Xen. Cyrop. 3.1.4, Now as those with the women in charge went forward they came upon the forces in the mountain[160]

 οἱ τιθέμενοι νόμους οἱ ἀσθενεῖς ἄνθρωποί εἰσιν καὶ οἱ πολλοί P. G. 483b,  the enactors of the laws are the weak men and the multitude

“τὰ τοῦ δήμου φρονεῖ” Ar. Eq. 1216,  is on the side of the people/He favors the people’s side.

“οἱ ἐπὶ τῶν πραγμάτων” D. 18.247, those in power, the government

“οἱ ἐν τῇ ἡλικίᾳ” T. 6.24, those in the prime of life

“τὰ τῶν στρατιωτῶν” X. A. 3.1.20, the condition of the soldiers

“τὰ τῆς ὀργῆς” T. 2.60, the outbursts of wrath

“οὐκ ἀπορήσετε τῶν ἐθελησόντων ὑπὲρ ὑμῶν κινδυνεύειν” D. 20.166, you will not be in want of those who will be willing to encounter danger for you

Art3. Pronominal[161]

Greek articles originally were demonstrative pronouns and the transition from the demonstrative to the article is so gradual that it is often impossible to distinguish between the two in earlier texts.

In Homer ὁ, ἡ, τό is usually a demonstrative pronoun and is used substantively or adjectively; it also serves as the personal pronoun of the third person:

“ἀλλὰ τὸ θαυμάζω” δ 655, but I marvel at this

τὸν λωβητῆρα ἐπεσβόλον B 275,  this prating brawler

τὴν δ᾽ ἐγὼ οὐ λύσω A 29, but her I will not release

τεύχεα δ᾽ ἐξενάριξε, τά οἱ πόρε χάλκεος Ἄρης H 146, he stripped off the arms that brazen Ares had given him

 In attic prose, the demonstrative force of ὁ, ἡ, τό survives chiefly in connection with particles (μέν, δέ, γέ, τοί; and with καί preceding ὁ). ὁ is a demonstrative commonly before μέν, δέ, and especially in contrasted expressions: ὁ μέν . . . ὁ δέ the one, this . . . the other, that, as in:

“οἱ μὲν ἐπορεύοντο, οἱ δ᾽ εἵποντο” X. A. 3.4.16,  the one party proceeded, the other followed

The reference may be indefinite; in which case τὶς is often added:

“τοὺς μὲν ἀπέκτεινε, τοὺς δ᾽ ἐξέβαλεν” X. A. 1.1.7,  some he put to death, and others he expelled

οἱ μέν τινες ἀπέθνῃσκον, οἱ δ᾽ ἔφευγον C. 3. 2. 10, some were killed, but others escaped

Art4. Generic[162]

The generic article denotes an entire class as distinguished from other classes. Thus, ὁ ἄνθρωπος man (as distinguished from other beings), οἱ γέροντες the aged.

δεῖ τὸν στρατιώτην φοβεῖσθαι μᾶλλον τὸν ἄρχοντα ἢ τοὺς πολεμίους X. A. 2.6.10, the (a) soldier should fear his commander rather than the enemy

“πονηρὸν ὁ συκοφάντης” D. 18.242, the informer is a vile thing

In the singular the generic article makes a single object the representative of the entire class; in the plural it denotes all the objects belonging to a class. The generic article is especially common, in the plural, with adjectives used substantively. A participle with the article may also denote an entire class.

“οὐκ ἄν τις εἴποι ὡς τοὺς κακούργους καὶ ἀδίκους εἴα καταγελᾶν” X. A. 1.9.13, no one could say that he permitted the malefactor and the wrongdoer to deride him

“οὐκ ἀπορήσετε τῶν ἐθελησόντων ὑπὲρ ὑμῶν κινδυνεύειν” D. 20.166,  you will not be in want of those who will be willing to encounter danger for you

οἱ λογοποιοῦντες D. 4. 49, newsmongers

“οἱ ἐθελήσοντες μένειν” X. H. 7.5.24, those who shall be willing to remain

τῆς πόλεως τὸ τιμώμενον T. 2. 63, the dignity of the State

Art5. Abstract concept[163]

Abstract substantives generally have the article:

“ἡ ἀρετὴ μᾶλλον ἢ ἡ φυγὴ σῴζει τὰς ψυχάς” X. C. 4.1.5, valour rather than flight saves men's lives

The article must be used when reference is made to a definite person or thing or to an object well known:

“ἡ τῶν Ἑλλήνων εὔνοια” Aes. 3.70, the goodwill of the Greeks

(ὑμῖν) ἡ σχολή D. 8.53, your usual idleness

However, the names of the virtues, vices, arts, sciences, occupations often omit the article.

τί σωφροσύνη, τί μανία; X. M. 1.1.16, what is temperance, what is madness?

ἀρχὴ φιλίας μὲν ἔπαινος, ἔχθρας δὲ ψόγος I. 1.33, praise is the beginning of friendship, blame of enmity

Art6. With proper names[164]

Proper names may take the article if they are previously mentioned or specially marked as well known. However, the use of articles with proper names depends on the style of the author.[165]

τοὺς στρατιώτας αὐτῶν, τοὺς παρὰ Κλέαρχον ἀπελθόντας, εἴα Κῦρος τὸν Κλέαρχον ἔχειν X. A. 1.4.7, their soldiers who seceded to Clearchus, Cyrus allowed Clearchus to retain

ὁ Σόλων D. 20.90, Solon

οἱ Ἡρακλέες P. Th. 169b, the Heracleses

Names of deities omit the article, except when emphatic (νὴ τὸν Δία by Zeus) or when definite cults are referred to. Names of nations may also omit the article.

τὸ τῆς Ἀθηνᾶς ἕδος I. 15.2,  the sanctuary of Athena (at Athens)

Art7. Possession[166]

The article often takes the place of an unemphatic possessive pronoun when there is no doubt as to the possessor.

“Κῦρος καταπηδήσας ἀπὸ τοῦ ἅρματος τὸν θώρακα ἐνέδυ” X. A. 1.8.3, Cyrus leaped down from his chariot and put on his breastplate

The pronoun αὐτός[167] 

Aut1. Emphatic

αὐτός is intensive when

a. Standing alone in the nominative case :

αὐτοὶ τὴν γῆν ἔσχον T. 1.114, they (the Athenians) seized the land themselves

Here αὐτός emphasizes the word understood and is not a personal pronoun.

B. In the predicate position with a substantive, or in agreement with a pronoun, in any case:

αὐτὸς ὁ ἀνήρ, ὁ ἀνὴρ αὐτός the man himself, αὐτοῦ τοῦ ἀνδρός, τοῦ ἀνδρὸς αὐτοῦ, etc.

In Homer αὐτός denotes the principal person or thing, in opposition to what is subordinate, and is intensive by contrast:

αὐτὸν καὶ θεράποντα Z 18, the man himself and his attendant

Special renderings of the emphatic αὐτός:

“αὐτὴ ἡ ἀλήθεια” Aes. 3.207,  the naked truth

τὸ πλέον τοῦ χωρίου αὐτὸ καρτερὸν ὑπῆρχε T. 4.4,  the greater part of the place was strong in itself (without artificial fortification)

“αὐτὰ τάδε” T. 1.139, merely this

“ἄνδρας οἳ καὶ τοῖς μὴ ἐπικαλουμένοις αὐτοὶ ἐπιστρατεύουσι” T. 4.60, men who uninvited turn their arms even against those who do not ask their assistance

Denoting The Master (said by a pupil or slave):

Αὐτὸς ἔφα Diog. Laert. 8.1. 46, the Master (Pythagoras) said it (ipse dixit)

“τίς οὗτος; Αὐτός. τίς Αὐτός; Σωκράτης” Ar. Nub. 220, Who's this? The Master. Who's the Master? Socrates

Aut2. Personal Pronoun

αὐτός when unemphatic and standing alone in the oblique cases means him, her, it, them.

“ἐκέλευον αὐτὴν ἀπιέναι” L. 1.12, they ordered her to depart

Aut3. Identicalness

After the article, in the attributive position, αὐτός in any case means same. Thus, ὁ αὐτὸς ἀνήρ, rarely (ὁ) ἀνὴρ ὁ αὐτός the same man.

“τοῦ αὐτοῦ θέρους” T. 4.58, in the same summer

“τὰ αὐτὰ ταῦτα” X. A. 1.1.7,  these same things

“οἱ τοὺς αὐτοὺς αἰεὶ περὶ τῶν αὐτῶν λόγους λέγοντες” Ant. 5.50,  the people who are continually making the same speeches about the same things

ἐγὼ μὲν ὁ αὐτός εἰμι, ἱμεῖς δὲ μεταβάλλετε T. 2.61,  I am the same, it is you who change

With a proper name or a word denoting an individual, the article is omitted

“αὐτὸς Μένων” X. A. 2.1.5, Menon himself

πρὸ αὐτοῦ βασιλέως X. A. 1. 7. 11, in front of the Great King himself

Aut3.3. The word emphasized may be an oblique case which must be supplied:

ἔλεγε δὲ καὶ αὐτὸς ὁ Βρασίδας τῇ Θεσσαλῶν γῇ καὶ αὐτοῖς (scil. τοῖς Θεσσαλοῖς) φίλος ὢν ἰέναι T. 4.78, and Brasidas himself also said that he came as a friend to the country of the Thessalians and to the Thessalians themselves

δεῖ τοίνυν τοῦτ᾽ ἤδη σκοπεῖν (scil. ἡμᾶς) αὐτούς  D. 2.2, we must forthwith consider this matter ourselves

Aut4. Reflexive[168]

Instead of the indirect ἑαυτοῦ, etc., the oblique cases of αὐτός may be used as a reflexive pronoun:

“ἐπειρᾶτο τοὺς Ἀθηναίους τῆς ἐς αὐτὸν ὀργῆς παραλύειν” T. 2.65, he tried to divert the Athenians from their anger against himself

When ἑαυτοῦ, etc. precede, αὐτοῦ, etc. are usual instead of the direct reflexive:

“τὴν ἑαυτοῦ γνώμην ἀπεφαίνετο Σωκράτης πρὸς τοὺς ὁμιλοῦντας αὐτῷ” X. M. 4.7.1, Socrates was wont to set forth his opinion to those who conversed with him”

Of the plural forms, ἡμῶν αὐτῶν, etc. may be either emphatic or reflexive; αὐτῶν ἡμῶν, etc. are emphatic only; but σφῶν αὐτῶν is only reflexive (αὐτῶν σφῶν is not used). In Homer αὐτόν may mean myself, thyself , or himself, and ἓ αὐτόν, οἷ αὐτῷ, etc. are either emphatic or reflexive.

[a]Also see Monro 74 about descriptive imperfect, which he argues sometimes is used "in a description along with Aorists for the sake of connexion and variety (i.e.in order to avoid a series of detached assertions)". One of his examples is Il.1.437-439. Here's Amelia's translation:

437. 2274351[δὲ] As for the men themselves[καὶ αὐτοὶ] they[0] made their way[they:βαῖνον] out[ἐκ] at[ἐπὶ] the[0] edge[ῥηγμῖνι] of the[0] sea[of:θαλάσσης].

438. 2274351a They[0] disembarked[they:ἐκ βῆσαν] the[0] sacrifice[ἑκατόμβην] for the[0] far-shooter[ἑκηβόλῳ] Apollo[for:Ἀπόλλωνι];

439. 2274352 And[δὲ] out of[ἐκ] the[0] sea-faring[ποντοπόροιο] ship[νηὸς] Chryseis[Χρυσηῒς] walked[she:βῆ].

[b]@gcrane2008@gmail.com 

The last sentence of this explanation from Kuehner 383b mentions that in Iranian languages imperfect is the main tense for narration, and I think this might actually explain why I think there we are explaining Greek Grammar in comparison to English. It's common to use imperfect for narration in Early Modern Persian prose, and therefore some of these categories sound unnatural to me.

Explanation from Kuehner 383b:

Auch bei den oben an zweiter Stelle genannten Verben erklärt sich das Imperfekt zumeist daraus, dass der thatsächliche Abschluss der Handlung (bei πέμπειν, πλεῖν u. a. die Erreichung des Zieles, bei κελεύειν, παρακελεύεσθαι u. a. die Ausführung des Befehls) entweder überhaupt nicht erfolgt ist oder ausser Betracht bleibt. Th. 4.28 Νικίας . . . ἐκέλευεν ἥν τινα βούλεται δύναμιν λαβόντα ἐπιχειρεῖν (erfolglose Aufforderung). 3, 112 τοὺς Μεσσηνίους πρώτους ἐπίτηδες ὁ Δημοσθένης προὔταξε καὶ προσαγορεύειν ἐκέλευε (nicht auf die Ausführung, sondern auf den Grund des Befehls kommt es an). 8, 6 ἀντὶ τοῦ Μελαγκρίδου Χαλκιδέα ἔπεμπον (der wirkliche Aufbruch erfolgt erst cap. 12). 3, 49 τριήρη εὐθὺς ἄλλην ἀπέστελλον κατὰ σπουδήν (Imperf., weil im folgenden erst noch geschildert wird, was unterwegs geschah). 1, 46 οἱ δὲ Κορίνθιοι . . ἔπλεον ἐπὶ τὴν Κέρκυραν ναυσὶ πεντήκοντα καὶ ἑκατόν. So steht das Imperfekt namentlich bei den Verben des Sagens, wenn die berichtete Rede dem Erzähler nicht schon als abgeschlossenes Ganzes vorschwebt, sondern in ihren einzelnen Momenten entwickelt wird. Th. 1.72 vor der Rede: οἱ Ἀθηναῖοι ἔλεγον τοιάδε, 79 nach Beendigung derselben aber τοιαῦτα δὲ οἱ Ἀ. εἶπον. X. A. 4.8.14 Ξενοφῶν δὲ ἀπιὼν ἔλεγε τοῖς στρατιώταις: Ἄνδρες, κτλ. Cy. 3. 3, 13 σὺν τούτοις οὖν ὁ Κῦρος ἐλθὼν πρὸς τὸν Κυαξάρην ἤρχετο λόγου τοιοῦδε. Bloss ἤρχετο An. 3. 2, 9. — Andere betrachten Imperfekte wie ἔλεγε als vereinzelte Überbleibsel aus einer älteren Sprachperiode, in der das Imperfekt noch das eigentliche Tempus der Erzählung war (wie im Sanskrit und im Iranischen). S. Delbrück, Syntakt. Forsc

[c]Häufig wird das Imperfekt gebraucht, wo man eine abgeschlossene, nicht eine noch in der Entwickelung begriffene Handlung ausgedrückt erwarten sollte, wo also das Imperfekt statt des Aoristes zu stehen scheint. Dieser Gebrauch findet sich besonders häufig in der Homerischen Sprache bei Verben, wie αἱρεῖν, βαίνειν, βάλλειν, διδόναι, ἱέναι, ἱστάναι, καλεῖν, λείπειν, πέμπειν, πίπτειν, τιθέναι u. a., und in der Prosa bei den Verben des Schickens und Gehens, als: πέμπειν, ἀποστέλλειν, πλεῖν, ἀνάγεσθαι u. a., sowie des Sagens, Ermunterns u. ähnl., z. B. λέγειν, ἀγγέλλειν, ἄρχεσθαι λόγου od. bloss ἄρχεσθαι, ἐρωτᾶν, κελεύειν, παρακελεύεσθαι u. a.7) Eine Vertauschung der Zeitformen anzunehmen ist durchaus unstatthaft. Wenn der Dichter die zuerst genannten Verben im Imperfekt gebraucht, so will er uns das handelnde Subjekt in seiner damaligen Situation vor die Augen stellen, während sich der Abschluss der Handlung nur aus dem Zusammenhange ergiebt. Kuehner 383b.

[d]Das Imperfekt scheint bisweilen statt des Präsens zu stehen, indem die durch dasselbe ausgedrückte Handlung in der Gegenwart fortbesteht. Der Redende nimmt alsdann keine Rücksicht auf das Fortbestehen der Handlung in der Gegenwart, sondern versetzt sich in den Zeitpunkt der Vergangenheit zurück, in welchem er dieselbe erkannte oder von ihr die Rede war. g, 292 ἔνθα . . τὰς μὲν (νῆας) Κρήτῃ ἐπέλασσεν, | ἧχι Κύδωνες ἔναιον, wo die K. wohnen; auch im Deutschen kann ebenso das Imperf. gebraucht werden: wo d. K. wohnten. Pl. Criton. 47, d διαφθεροῦμεν ἐκεῖνο καὶ λωβησόμεθα, ὃ τῷ μὲν δικαίῳ βέλτιον ἐγίγνετο, τῷ δὲ ἀδίκῳ ἀπώλλυτο (statt: ὃ τῷ μὲν δικ. βέλτιον γίγνεσθαι, τῷ δὲ ἀδ. ἀπόλλυσθαι ἐλέγετο ἑκάστοτε ὑφ᾽ ἡμῶν περὶ τῶν τοιούτων διαλεγομένων, ubi v. Stallb.) Vgl. Cic. de offic. I. 40, 143: itaque quae erant prudentiae propria, suo loco dicta sunt. Civ. 406, e ἆῤ, ἦν δ̓ ἐγώ, ὅτι ἦν τι αὐτῷ ἔργον ὃ εἰ μὴ πράττοι οὐκ ἐλυσιτέλει ζῆν, was Stallb. erklärt: ὅτι ἐστὶν αὐτῷ, ὡς ἄρτι ἐλέγομεν,

Kühners ausführl. Griech. Grammatik. II. T. 1. Abt. 10

Phaedr. 230, a ἀτάρ, ὦ ἑταῖρε, μεταξὺ τῶν λόγων, ἆρ᾽ οὐ τόδε ἦν τὸ δένδρον, ἐφ᾽ ὅπερ ἦγες ἡμᾶς, ubi v. Stallb., wie auch im Deutschen: war das nicht der Baum? Th. 1.63 ἀπεῖχε δὲ ἑξήκοντα μάλιστα σταδίους καὶ ἔστι καταφανές. X. [e]Wir gebrauchen in diesem Falle das Präsens, indem wir die auf die Gegenwart sich erstreckende Folgerung ausdrücken. p, 420 Ἀντίνὀ, ὕβριν ἔχων, κακομήχανε, καὶ δέ σέ φασιν ἐν δήμῳ Ἰθάκης μεθ᾽ ὁμήλικας ἔμμεν᾽ ἄριστον βουλῇ καὶ μύθοισι: σὺ δ̓ οὐκ ἄρα τοῖος ἔησθα, man sagt zwar, du seiest ein vortrefflicher Mann; nun aber sehe ich nach den Erfahrungen, die ich machte, ein, dass du nicht ein solcher bist, Griech.: warst du nicht ein solcher (und bist es daher auch nicht). Vgl. ν, 209 f. l, 553 οὐκ ἄρ᾽ ἔμελλες . . λήσεσθαι . .; S. Ph. 978 οἴμοι: πέπραμαι κἀπόλωλ̓: ὅδ᾽ ἦν ἄρα | ὁ ξυλλαβών με, ja nun weiss ich es, Odysseus ist es, der mich hintergangen hat; Griech.: Odysseus also war es (und ist es daher auch). Eur. M. 703 ξυγγνωστὰ μέντ᾽ ἄρ᾽ ἦν σε λυπεῖσθαι, γύναι. P. Phaed. 68b οὐκοῦν ἱκανόν σοι τεκμήριον τοῦτο ἀνδρός, ὃν ἂν ἴδῃς ἀγανακτοῦντα μέλλοντα ἀποθανεῖσθαι, ὅτι οὐκ ἄρ᾽ ἦν φιλόσοφος, ἀλλά τις φιλοσώματος.9）(Smyth 1901)

Anmerk. 1. In Meldungen der Boten kann st. des Präsens auch das Imperfekt gebraucht werden, indem der Bote auf die Zeit Rücksicht nimmt, in welcher er einen Auftrag erhielt. Ar. Ach. 1073 ἰέναι ς᾿ ἐκέλευον οἱ στρατηγοὶ τήμερον | ταχέως λαβόντα τοὺς λόχους. Vgl. Horat. sat. II, 6, 35 u. 37 Roscius orabat sibi adesses ad Puteal cras.

Anmerk. 2. Über das Imperf. der Verben νικᾶν, κρατεῖν, ἡττᾶσθαι u. s. w. s. § 382, 4, c), über das Imperf. einer beabsichtigten Handlung s. § 382, 7, über die Imperfekte ἔδει, ἐχρῆν u. s. w. s. § 392^

I'm wondering if this use of the imperfect is similar to impf5 or impf7. Is there an actual semantic difference between these three (impf 5, 7, and 8), or the categories of Smyth are influenced by how we translate Greek to English? In other words, are we making a distinction here based on English Grammar?

Maybe we could explain all of them by referring to the "stage-setting" use of the imperfect as we see in Cambridge Grammar 33.51.

[g]wenn die durch das Imperfekt ausgedrückte Handlung mit einer anderen vergangenen Handlung verbunden ist, so kann es eine Handlung ausdrücken, welche entweder mit jener gleichzeitig war oder erst nachher eintrat, oder schon vorher stattfand.8) In dem letzteren Falle gebraucht das Deutsche, wie das Lateinische oft das Plusquamperfekt, während das Griechische, das eine Ausdrucksform für die Vorvergangenheit überhaupt nicht ausgebildet hat, die Nebenhandlung nur in ihrer Entwickelung vorführt, ihr zeitliches Verhältnis zur Haupthandlung aber unbezeichnet lässt. p, 50 τοῖσιν δὲ κρειῶν πίνακας παρέθηκε συβώτης | ὀπταλέων, ἅ ῥα τῇ προτέρῃ ὑπέλειπον (reliquerant) ἔδοντες. Hdt. 8.42 ἐναυμάχεον pugnaverant. Th. 8, 26 ἐλθόντος δὲ Ἀλκιβιάδου . . πυνθάνονται τὰ περὶ τῆς μάχης: παρῆν (affuerat) γὰρ ὁ Ἀλκιβιάδης καὶ ξυνεμάχετο τοῖς Μιλησίοις. 2, 23 ἀπέστειλαν τὰς ἑκατὸν ναῦς, ἅσπερ παρεσκευάζοντο, mit deren Ausrüstung sie damals (bei den cap. 17 besprochenen Kriegsvorbereitungen) beschäftigt waren. 2, 83 στρατηγοὶ δὲ ἦσαν κατὰ πόλεις ἑκάστων οἳ παρεσκευάζοντο, die die Rüstungen besorgt hatten. 4, 9 ἐτείχιζον. X. A. 1.2.22 (Κῦρος) εἶδε τὰς σκηνάς, οὗ οἱ Κίλικες ἐφύλαττον, ubi Cilices excubabant (näml. ehe Kyros erschien). 1. 4, 2 ἔχων ναῦς ἑτέρας Κύρου πέντε καὶ εἴκοσιν, αἷς ἐπολιόρκει Μίλητον, ὅτε Τισσαφέρνει φίλη ἦν. 1. 6, 10 ἐπεὶ εἶδον αὐτὸν οἵπερ πρόσθεν προσεκύνουν, καὶ τότε προσεκύνησαν. 3. 4, 7 ἐνταῦθα πόλις ἦν ἐρήμη: ᾤκουν δ̓ αὐτὴν τὸ παλαιὸν Μῆδοι, wo wir auch sagen können: dieselbe bewohnten ehemals die M. st. hatten bewohnt. Vgl. 3. 4, 10. 4. 3, 7. Antiph. 5.29 τὸ πλοῖον ἧκεν, ἐν ᾧ ἐπλέομεν, wo wir sagen: in dem wir gefahren waren, s. Maetzner ad. H. Smyth 1906
